questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding learning in psychology?
options: The psychology of learning focuses on how people learn and how they interact with the environments in which they have not learnt
Learning does not involve any changes in the organism
Learning is a relatively temporary change in behavior

questions.question: In order to say that learning has occurred, a/an ___ must occur during the lifetime of the organism.
Learning changes the ___ through the process of continuous interactions between the learner and the external environment.
options: chemical structure of the spinal cord

questions.question: Watson, one of the first psychologists to study learning and behavior is known for the ___.
Which of the following is not explored and described by the psychology of learning?
The state of ___ may be valuable at the start of a learning experience.
___ is the decrease in the response that an organism gives to a stimulus to which it is exposed in numerous trials or occasions.
Cooperative learning is shaped by three crucial elements. Which of the following is one of them?
Which of the following psychologists is an important contributor to the concept of observational learning?
Which of the following is not considered a pioneer of the behaviorism school of thought in psychology?
___ is known as the father of modern psychology.
Cognitivists objected to behaviorists because they felt that behaviorists ignored the important role of ___.
___ is viewed as the mainstream for all research on learning designs.
___ is a perspective in psychology focusing on the belief that human consciousness cannot be broken down into its elements and is based on the concept of a ‘whole’.
Theory of multiple intelligences is given by ___.
The general intelligence factor, also known as g, is what intelligence tests typically measure and refers only to ___ intelligence.
Cognitive evaluation for planning, attention, simultaneous, and successive processing of individuals can be done through CAS based on PASS theory. CAS here stands for ___.
BBL is a new science that shapes the learning process and is an approach that is based on the structure and function of the human brain. BBL stands for ___.
Gagne’s Conditions of Learning is also known as ___ Events of Instruction.
Which of the following is not a type of constructivism?
Which of the following is not one of the three major processes involved in memory?
___ refers to changing information into a usable form.
___ refers to a range of mental processes relating to the acquisition, storage, manipulation and retrieval of information.
Which of the following is a challenge faced by people with social cognition deficits?
options: A. talking too much to people
C. difficulty in reading facial expressions
D. difficulty in getting good academic scores
questions.correctAnswer: C. difficulty in reading facial expressions

questions.question: Which of the following is not true about the assumptions underlying the Information Processing View of Learning?
options: A. Information processing is analogous to computer processing
B. The human information processing system is interactive
C. There is no limit on how much information can be processed at each stage
D. Information is processed in steps
questions.correctAnswer: C. There is no limit on how much information can be processed at each stage

questions.question: ___ prevents the quick disappearance of information from short term memory.
The Multicomponent Model of Working Memory is largely attributed to the work by ___
___ memory refers to the events that can be reported from a person’s life.
The memory capacity depends on which of the following?
options: B. spatial and temporal correlations between memories
C. specific way memories are retrieved

questions.question: Which of the following is not one of the three measurable dimensions of cognitive load?
The three main types of thinking in psychology include the following except ___
Young children engaging in imaginative play often engage in ___ thinking.
Which of the following is a way in which we think?
People experience the ___ experience when they find the solution to a problem suddenly that had been in their mind for hours or days, late.
___ knowledge refers to knowledge of terminology and specific details.
Which of the following is not true about metacognition?
options: allows people to be dependent on others for their learning
often referred to as “thinking about thinking”
is crucial for efficient independent learning because it fosters self-reflection
is a regulatory system that helps a person understand and control his or her own cognitive performance
questions.correctAnswer: allows people to be dependent on others for their learning

questions.question: Which of the following is not an effective way to develop reflective thinking?
Which of the following is not true about creative thinking?
options: It is the ability to consider something in a new way
It is not a skill anybody can develop
It is the process of nurturing our imagination
It is all about developing innovative solutions to problems.
E. It requires a compilation of analytical, problem-solving, organizational and communication skills
questions.correctAnswer: It is not a skill anybody can develop

questions.question: The ___ stage of the creative thinking process refers to the ‘eureka’ moment.
In a concept map, two nodes connected with a labeled arrow are called a ___.
Which of the following is not a causal factor for extrinsic motivation?
___ refers to realizing the value of developing a skill/behavior.
Drive theory is a psychological concept that attempts to explain why and how people behave in the ways they do. It is given by ___.
___ theory that suggests that people are motivated to take action in order to receive a reward and is based on the idea of operant conditioning.
The Yerkes Dodson law gives ___ relationship between arousal and performance.
The expectancy theory is based on the assumption that ___.
options: our behavior is based on making a conscious choice from a set of possible alternative behaviors
individuals are motivated to seek out stimulation when they have low levels of arousal, but will become bored and unmotivated when they become too highly aroused
biological needs produce unpleasant states of arousal which people seek to reduce
questions.correctAnswer: our behavior is based on making a conscious choice from a set of possible alternative behaviors

questions.question: Valence, or the perceived value of reward, would have ___ value if one wants to avoid that rewar
Which of the following is not true about Maslow’s need hierarchy?
options: Needs lower down in the hierarchy must be satisfied before individuals can attend to higher needs
Safety needs lie at the bottom of the pyramid
Deficiency needs are concerned with basic survival
Growth needs are more psychological needs
E. Motivation is seen as being not just concerned with tension reduction and survival but also with human growth and development
questions.correctAnswer: Safety needs lie at the bottom of the pyramid

questions.question: Self-Determination Theory differentiates between ___ and ___ motivation types.
In achievement motivation, the motive to avoid failure often consists of ___.
options: worries about the consequences of failing

questions.question: Daniel Goleman’s work in emotional intelligence (EI) has outlined ___ main areas of this intelligence.
Which of the following statements is not true?
options: Experts even suggested that emotional intelligence/ EQ, is more important than IQ/academic intelligence
An individual with high EI is not only aware of what emotions they are feeling but can put words to their feelings
Studies show that EI does not impact aspects of one’s life like academic performance
Peter Salovey and John Mayer were the first to develop a psychological theory of emotional intelligence.
questions.correctAnswer: Studies show that EI does not impact aspects of one’s life like academic performance

questions.question: ___ refers to how tuned to the emotions of others a person is.
The following are advantages of developing emotional intelligence, except------
options: Being able to accept criticism and responsibility
Knowing why we do the things we do
Being able to say no when we need to
Being able to hide our feelings from others
questions.correctAnswer: Being able to hide our feelings from others

questions.question: The Pyramid of Emotional Intelligence is also known as the ___ layer model.
EI can be developed at any stage of life through self-effort & training.
When someone engages in___, they can regulate their emotions to ensure that others feel more comfortable.
The management of emotions is ___.
options: influenced by cultural and social norms
done by actively shaping and directing feelings

questions.question: ___ is seen when workers change their outward emotional expressions but do not attempt to feel the emotions that they are displaying.
The concept of emotional contagion can be linked to biological basis of ___.
___ defined learning as ‘a change in human disposition or capacity that persists over a period of time and is not simply ascribable to processes of growth.

The principles of contiguity (how close in time two events must be for a bond to be formed) and reinforcement (any means of increasing the likelihood that an event will be repeated) are central to explaining the learning process in the ___ orientation to learning.
Which of the following is not true about humanistic orientations to learning?
options: It has a quality of personal involvement
The locus of evaluation resides definitely outside the learner
questions.correctAnswer: The locus of evaluation resides definitely outside the learner

questions.question: The concept of situated learning is studied under which school of thought of learning theories?
Which of the following is not one of the individual variable factors affecting learning?
___ learners prefer maps, graphs, diagrams and charts to learn.
___ learners search for connections, causes, patterns, and results in their learning.
Effective instruction is ___.
options: designed to accommodate student learning needs and styles

questions.question: ___ role of the trainer consists of transmitting information about a subject to the audience.
Which of the following is not a component of the ADDIE model?
The word ‘pedagogy’ has been derived from the Greek word “pedagogue” which stands for___.
Which of the following statements is not true about pedagogy?
options: It assists both students and teachers in gaining an in-depth understanding of fundamental material.
It is about suppressing responses from learners
It enables teachers to influence student learning with an intention to capture the attention of students
questions.correctAnswer: It is about suppressing responses from learners

questions.question: Which of the following is not a pedagogical approach in teaching?
___ is a form of active learning that starts by posing questions, problems or scenarios rather than simply presenting established facts or portraying a smooth path to knowledge.
Which of the following is a primary role of the instructor in experiential learning?
The ‘what is important?’ stage of the experiential learning process refers to the ___ stage.
The ___ learning style as given by Kolb suggests that these individuals prefer to look at things from multiple perspectives and prefer to watch rather than do.
The following factors influence preferred learning styles except___.
Integrative learning often involves three steps. Which of the following is not one of them?
In transformative learning, ___ includes a student’s habit of the mind, as well as a personal point of view.
E-learning implies ___ learning.
___ type of e-learning is highly interactive, which includes graphics, video, audio and games too.
Which of the following is not true about e-learning?
options: one can have access to the content any number of times
it helps in developing new policies
it saves time for the students, they don’t need to travel to the institution
it is targeted to cater to the needs of students specifically
questions.correctAnswer: it is targeted to cater to the needs of students specifically

questions.question: As learning depends on the learner’s prior experience, and no two learners will have the same experiences, new information will be dealt with in different ways by different learners. This statement means that learning is ___.
Which of the following is a way of facilitating the social dimension to learning?
We can say that when we're good at something after practice, it's usually because ___
options: our brain has released better chemicals
our brain has made stronger connections with this information
our brain has prioritized this information over others
questions.correctAnswer: our brain has made stronger connections with this information

questions.question: Learners may multitask when engaging in an online course, which could be resulting in ___.
The cognitive load theory suggests that when we overload our___, we are unable to acquire and process new information.
There are five critical aspects of psychology which are needed to guarantee the implementation of successful eLearning. Which of the following is not one of them?

___ is a learning tool, because the explicit navigation of the topic and association types might enable meaningful learning and it helps to reduce the cognitive loads caused by E-learning content and constant attention.
The Readiness Model for New Normal in Education designed by many educational institutions caters to the following components except ___.
In 2018, Global Education and Skills Forum noted that the ‘future’ teacher would need some skills to thrive in the 21st century. Which of the following is not one of them?
Which of the following impacts student learning?
options: Their perception about their intelligence and ability

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true?
options: Techniques linked to self-control contribute to more effective learning if taught and applied correctly
Clear, explanatory and timely feedback to students is important for learning
Students tend to enjoy learning and have better outcomes when their motivation is more extrinsic than intrinsic
questions.correctAnswer: Students tend to enjoy learning and have better outcomes when their motivation is more extrinsic than intrinsic

questions.question: Both formative and summative assessment are important and useful, provided they are applied and interpreted appropriately.
Individual differences are the unique ways each human being differs from another. It can be handled through using different techniques. Which of the following is not one of them?
Clapping is an example of ___ rewar
___ is the process of judging the value or worth of an individual's achievements or characteristics.
___ refers to the frequent, interactive assessment of student progress to identify learning needs and shape teaching.
"That is an intelligent response, well done" is an example of a ___ level feedback.
___ refers to a complex set of mental abilities underlying social stimulus perception, processing, interpretation, and response.
Piaget’s conception of ___ views information inconsistent with an individual’s cognitive structures as an initiator for assimilation and accommodation processes.

During the earliest stages of development, children see the world from their own perspective and struggle to think about how other people may view the worl This highlights that initially, children are ___.
Which of the following is false regarding social cognition?
options: It develops in childhood and adolescence
When looking at a social situation, any two people may have wildly different interpretations.
It includes complex abilities like theory of mind
There are no cultural differences in social cognition
questions.correctAnswer: There are no cultural differences in social cognition

questions.question: Social processes influence how information is selected, organized, integrated, and retrieve This highlights the ___ hypothesis.
The social cognitive theory is developed by ___.
___ refers to the internal or external responses to a person's behavior that affect the likelihood of continuing or discontinuing the behavior.
Observational learning occurs through the sequence of ___ number of processes. One of those is attentional processes.
The ___ model of observational learning involves an actual individual demonstrating or acting out a behavior.
___ suggests that our behavior, personal factors, and environmental factors all influence each other.
Sustainable development is ___.
Revenue generation and resource use are components of ___.
___ as a practice is defined as solving social problems using market based methods and can create both economic and social value.
In the context of sustainability, HESI highlights the role of ___ in building a better world for current and future generations.
The following are the outcome targets of SDG 4, except ___.
One of the means to implement SDG 4 is exponentially increasing the number of scholarships available to developing contexts.
Successful implementation of ESD requires a shift in focus from ___.
___ refers to the ability to understand and evaluate multiple possible futures to deal with risks and changes.
Fostering competencies requires integration of three interrelated dimensions of learning as described by UNESCO. Which of the following is not one of them?
GAP in the context of Education for Sustainable Development stands for ___.
